title: BCA's Reed is right for the times
text:
Incoming Business Council of Australia president Tim Reed has got what it takes to become the voice of reason amidst the mass of voices clamouring for public attention across a range of important economic policy debates.

In his first public outing ahead of taking over from Grant King in November, Reed showed he is a consummate communicator. He is at ease with journalists and able to explain in a convincing way the crucial role of business in a prosperous society.

On Thursday he was across the topical and intense debates over the forced divestment of assets by energy companies, NBN’s sudden and unusual push into business fibre connections and allegations by the Prime Minister Scott Morrison of major bank “profiteering”.

Incoming Business Council of Australia president, Tim Reed, knows the important of big and small business working together. Louie Douvis

He was not afraid to express opinions at odds with federal and state government policies. Nor has he been cowed by the repeated attacks by federal government ministers and assistant ministers against business leaders who have championed social issues.

Reed’s 12 years running the accounting software company MYOB has given him valuable insights into the symbiotic relationship between large and small business. He believes the role of business in society must be guided by leaders with integrity who behave ethically.

At MYOB Reed told his executive team to approach all internal discussions with the assumption that it could be viewed by customers. This is a variation of the “front page test” used by sensible CEOs for decades.

Reed says he will work closely with BCA chief executive Jennifer Westacott to push three policy priorities: the implementation of immigration and educational policies to deal with the skills shortage, reduction in regulation to help boost productivity and ensuring Australia’s corporate tax system is made to be competitive.
description: The Business Council of Australia has opted for a generational change with the appointment of Tim Reed, 49, as president when Grant King retires in November. The former MYOB chief executive is not afraid to express opinions that conflict with the government.
